course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Quantitative Social Analysis
course.description: This survey course introduces students to quantitative social analysis by showing how such techniques are used to examine important social science topics as health, business, education, inequality, family and kinship, careers, crime, migration, and economic, social and political change. For these and other topics, the class presents examples of classic as well recent studies that make exemplary use of data and methods, and which have advanced our understanding of the relevant phenomena. The class will also introduce the major sources of data for quantitative social analysis, with an emphasis on ones that are publicly available. Along the way, students will learn about the differences between the concerns, paradigms, and methodologies of the major social science disciplines. Strengths and limitations of quantitative techniques for the study of social phenomenon will be discussed, as will the relationship of quantitative approaches to other methodologies.

reviews.author: JundeHK
reviews.comment_content: Designed specifically for QSA freshmen. The intentional outcome is to furnish students with a general picture of how social research is conducted, what are its components and how to construct them. The first month's worth of classes is devoted to explaining terms and fundamental knowledge, whereas in the second half of the semester, guest speakers, all professors from the division of social science, take turns to deliver lessons regarding their fields of research and also to advertise their current project.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Interesting enough. Prof.Tang has the power of explaining complex things in a way that one could easily understand and grasp the crucial idea. Also, any questions raised by the students, even the most trivial ones, will always receive a most detailed and patient answer.

One heads-up: Don't whisper or murmur or talk in any way during the class(except to ask questions of course), he hates that.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class exercise for taking attendance, pop-up quiz, no midterm, several essays, final exam canceled due to the protest.
Hard to get a good grade, don't miss any attendance, although if you do have a good reason for absent, you can always send emails to explain your situation to procure leaves.
One complaint is that the assignments, mostly essays, are not graded by the professor but by the TA. This said practice makes the grades a bit unprofessional and inaccurate.
The syllabus is enclosed for further references to the grading scheme.
reviews.comment_workload: Depends. At first, an essay of 500 words could be quite a time-consumer. Yet as time proceeds, I dare say that you'll find your faculty of both the intake and the output sharpens rapidly. So don't be so alarmed if you find facing an essay assignment consisted of more than ten pages. By that time, it would be merely a "bedtime writing" for you. :)

reviews.author: garbage
reviews.title: OMG this is strenuous. Hard work pays off!
reviews.comment_content: The main part is the principles and the basic concepts of quantitative social analysis. There are guest speakers  who introduce their fields of study. Overall, pretty practical and interesting, I guess?
reviews.comment_teaching: So far, I think the overall teaching is good. The main instructor explain the concepts clearly and most of the guests from the social science department have interesting topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
The instructor has been changed and from the reviews in the past two years this is supposed to be a good grade class. If you got 80%+ and then you get an A-. However, due to the new grading system, which is shown in the course syllabus, you should get higher than 90% only to get an A-!
This year the final exam is changed into a project, which is a complete research project on one's own, taking up 30% of the final score. The mean for the project is 20.3.
The mean for the final grade is 83.2, which is a B due to the syllabus. Pretty good grade!
Personally I got 30/30 in the final research project and 98.5 for the final score, and it turned out A+! A dummy like me can obtain an A+! If you put your heart in it, which means submit EVERY HOMEWORK on time and choose interesting topics in the reflections and the final project, you would be fine and get a really good grade! It really depends on how hard-working you are instead of IQ.
reviews.comment_workload:
Despite the fact that you have to compose a whole research report, which is about above 1500 words, you ought to finish 3 reflections. You should also read the materials given since there will be quizzes on them, which is about 150 pages in total. There are also frequently in-class quizzes which sometimes turn out to be tricky. But you would get the points if you answer, no matter correct or not. And you have to propose 15 questions for the final exam.
Since the last reflection is reduced and the final exam is reduced, the workload of the course this semester is pretty light! The final project contains about 4k-5k words, I think. (Mine has 4775 words and 14 pages.)

reviews.comment_workload: Has minor work every week, can be annoying but in general, it is very light. Final was open book and final questions were prepared by students, therefore already posted on canvas.

reviews.author: FatCow
reviews.comment_content: The course included different topics in various aspects. At the beginning of the course, the first 6-7 lessons would be held by Professor Tang and afterward the lessons were held by the invited speakers. Some topics were listed below as examples: social network analysis, environment and well-being, policy analysis, demography, relationship between natural resources and violence in Xinjiang... These all depend on the guest speakers (not sure whether Professor Tang will invite the same guests in the coming year).
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Tang is nice. He would answer all your questions and even tell jokes in lessons. Our in-class test was not pretty well and he would go through and discuss the question once. The pathway of a research paper was clearly taught by him, students should be able to catch them up easier. For other guest speakers, some speakers were bored but you may still learn something from their research areas (not really much, if you find it interesting, you should enroll their courses, they must advertise their courses during lessons.)
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is pretty high in each assignment but it does NOT represent that you get a good grade.
In this semester, the weighting has been changed for a few times.

There should be 3 reflections about the topics originally but we were required to write 2 only at last. The assignment 7.1 replaced the final exam and if you receive a nice mark it will rise your final grade.

The marks that I got:
reflection 1            4/5
reflection 2         4.5/5
assignment 7.1   30/30
I even missed a mc question and other assignments got 3-4 out of 4

My final got 94 and got an A
The mean probably got a B-/B
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload was appropriate as I did not read all the research paper :( For the in-class quiz, you should revise your notes and REMEMBER to jot notes in each lesson.

NO MID-TERM!!! NO PRESENTATION!!!

The largest workload was your research paper. However, if you choose an adequate and your favorite topic, it will be fine.

reviews.author: yfl
reviews.comment_content: there will be guest sharing on each lesson. The sharing is mainly about the research methods in social science. After the sharing, there will be a Q&A session. If there's no sharing on that day, the lesson is likely to become a Q&A session, which is the professor might ask some of the students to ask their questions and he will answer them.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite heavy for me personally. Before each lesson, you have to ask a question on Canvas and your question will be graded from 0 to 5. On the lesson, after the sharing of the guests, you have to ask questions in order to gain the participation mark. You also have to write a reflection once a month.

reviews.author: PTMS
reviews.title: Compulsory course for year 1 QSA student
reviews.comment_content:
It cover almost all social science discipline
Including psychology, economy, political science, public policy, demography and other disciplines.
It will be a interesting course if you like social science, and can provide you a brief and wide understanding of each social science discipline.
reviews.comment_teaching:
As Cameron is the coordinator of this course, he will appear in this course every time, but all he does is just take attendance. So you better not skip your lesson as he can memorize who have enrolled in this lesson.
Every lesson will be featured with different guest lecturer, mostly from HKUST, but some of them are from other university as well, and they will talk about different social science discipline by talking about their research or briefly talk about the course content that they are teaching.
Although there are some boring lecturer, most of them are interesting and able to bring some new insights to me.
Also, because all of them use english as teaching medium, if you are not good at english you will find it quite difficult to follow (eg me)
reviews.comment_grading:
It composed with 6 different part
according to canvas, the weighting of different tasks are:
3 Reflection 30%
Exam 20% ( mean ~65/80)
6 Proposed question for exam 20%
Attendance 10%
Uncountable discussion topics 10%
Participation 10%
I have got total 83.92% and turnout A-
for your reference,
my 1st reflection 3.5/5 2nd 4.5/5 3rd 4.5/5
exam 69/80
Discussion question full
All 6 Proposed question total  25/30
attendance full
participation 0
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy I would say.
Before every lesson you are required to read readings which are provided by the upcoming guest lecturer, and many of them are research paper that has a ton of difficult words and very long, if will be a hard time for people who not good at english. Also, after reading those papers, you are required to post a discussing question in canvas for the upcoming lesson.
Every two weeks you are requested to post a mc question that related to the topic in past two weeks that will appear in final exam.
Every month you need to write a reflection in 400- 500 words that is about your interested social science discipline which is about your thoughts, new insight etc about this discipline.
The easiest part for this course i think is the final exam, because you can bring your cheat sheet (A4 for both side) and all the question were posted and can be viewed in canvas.

reviews.author: reosaki
reviews.title: Introductory to Quantitative Social Analysis - -
reviews.comment_content:
It covers everything.

The course can be divided into 2 parts. The first is the videos. You are required to watch them online. In the video, you can see how Cameron do the presentation... I'm just kidding. The video mainly focuses on introducing basic knowledge of social science research.

The second part is the lecture. Different instructors with different research interests are invited to the class. Case analysis is the most interesting part of the lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cameron is nice and patient. He served as a guide in this semester for QSA students.

As for other instructors, once you concentrate on their research, you will never find this course boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments are weighted by group:
Reflection 30%
Discussion Topics 10%
Attendance 10%
Proposed Questions for the Final Exam 20%
Final Exam 20%
Participation - Assigned 10%

According to the critera:
Reflection 90% 13.50 / 15.00
Discussion Topics 100% 17.00 / 17.00
Attendance 100% 20.00 / 20.00
Participation 95% 19.00 / 20.00
Proposed Questions for the Final Exam 86.67% 26.00 / 30.00
Final Exam 87.5% 70.00 / 80.00
Excluded 100% 3.00 / 3.00
Participation - Assigned 100% 100.00 / 100.00
Total 91.83%(A)

It seems that A+ requires 95%+.
However, it's applicable to me.
So plz be modest and precise to every assignment.
reviews.comment_workload:
It's OK for a social science course.

On average every week you need to write 2-3 questions on Canvas, do the reading within 20 pages (and some of them are optional). Every month with a simple reflection.
That's all.

Cameron don't teach much directly since it is basically sharing of many guests but the flow of the class is alright.

It is fun that professor gave us links of his online courses and told us to watch them, yet it is pretty much unrelated with the exam or whatsoever, and that most of the students just dont watch them at all. LOL
reviews.comment_grading: Just make sure you don't miss any online assignment (like I do) then you should be alright
reviews.comment_workload:
Barely nothing at all honestly, some less than 50 words questions that if you ask something you are pretty much guaranteed to have all the point, some proposed questions for the final and some reflection.

The questions student proposed will be the questions in the final exam, which you should do well if you read your classmates' work, but the problem is that sometimes the quality of the questions might not be very good.

reviews.author: Alexia
reviews.comment_content: This course is quite interesting as we had a lot of guests thoughtout the semester who came to present their research and discuss with us important topics that can usually be linked to current events. It's a highly interactive course.

He has more of a passive role in this course, as he makes sure many guests will attend the course, but doesn't teach directly the course's content
reviews.comment_grading:
There is no midterm.
Participation : 10%

reviews.comment_workload: Workload is alright, but be aware that you will always have something to prepare before the class.
